_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressor packages, vessels, evaporators, condensors, valves, liquid pumps,

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Reinhart Foodservice LLC / Agar is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility. 



Reinhart Foodservice LLC / Agar (Reinhart) senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Reinhart's safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration system are administered by the Facility Maintenance Manager, who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Evaporative Condensers to the Thermosyphon Receiver.  The Thermosyphon Receiver maintains a minimum liquid level to deliver ammonia to the compressors for oil cooling and routes the excess liquid ammonia to the High Pressure Receiver.  

 

The High Pressure Receiver feeds high temperature liquid ammonia to the +18?F High Temperature Recirculator. The +18?F High Temperature Recirculator then pumps high temperature recirculated liquid to the -20?F Low Temperature Recirculator and to the following evaporators:

 

?         +40?F Perishable Truck Dock (AU1-12)

?         +42?F Dry Produce (AU13-15)

?         +50?F Dry Produce (AU16-19)

?         +32?F Wet Produce (AU20-24)

?         +32?F Fish Cooler (AU25)    

?         +32?F Processed Meat Cooler (AU27-30)

?         +28?F Fresh Meat Cooler (AU31-38)

?         +28?F Poultry Cooler (AU39-40)

?         Ice Maker (NIS)

 

The +18?F High Temperature Recirculator receives high temperature recirculated suction (liquid/vapor mix) from the

se evaporators, wherein the liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and vapor rises to the top which is drawn off by Compressors RC-1, RC-2, & RC-3.    

 

The -20?F Low Temperature Recirculator pumps low temperature recirculated liquid ammonia to the -10?F Freezer Evaporators (AU41-46), from which a liquid/vapor mix returns to the recirculator as low temperature recirculated suction.  Suction is drawn off the top of the vessel by Compressors RC-4 & RC-5.   

 

At the evaporators, fans are used to transfer heat from the product in the room to the ammonia within the system.  The liquid ammonia, flowing through coils in the unit, is partially boiled as it absorbs heat from the product and room.  The resulting high stage 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) from Evaporators AU1-40 is returned to the +18?F High Temperature Recirculator.  The resulting low stage 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) from the -10?F Freezer Evaporators (AU41-46) is returned to the -20?F Low Temperature Recirculator. 

 

Compressors RC-1, RC-2, and RC-3 are high stage compressors, which draw high stage suction from the +18?F High Temperature Recirculator.  The high stage compressors raise the pressure of the vapor and then discharge to the Evaporative Condensers, to the Glycol Heat Exchangers (GHX1 & GHX2) for underfloor heating, to the Thaw Room Evaporator (AU26) for humidity control (when in service), and to the evaporators for coil defrost.  Compressors RC-4 and RC-5 draw low stage suction from the -20?F Low Temperature Recirculator.  Compressor RC-4 discharges to the +18?F High Temperature Recirculator, while Compressor RC-5 discharges to the Evaporative Condensers.   All compressors receive high pressure liquid from the Thermosyphon Receiver for oil cooling purposes. 

 

At the Evaporative Condensers, air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the compressor discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the Thermosyphon Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again.  T

he system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensables, i.e. air, from the system.

 

The ASME vessels and compressor oil separators are equipped with pressure relief valves.  All of the relief valves are tied into a common relief header that vent to the atmosphere.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Reinhart ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  Facility maintenance personnel complete a shift log noting operating parameters. All other preventative maintenance and all minor/major repairs are completed by an outside contractor.



The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable codes at the time of construction, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room as well as sensors in the cold rooms and vent line.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that relieve to the atmosphere.



Reinhart has developed a preventive maintenance program that utilizes the services of a professional refrigeration contractor to complete regularly scheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia refrigeration system as well as repairs as needed to process equipment.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release of 10 pounds in the past five years.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulti

ng from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.

 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Reinhart has an emergency action plan.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



  1.)  To save lives.

  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.)  To protect the environment.

  4.)  To minimize property damage.



The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.



In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facility's action plan to respond to the situation.  If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted in December 2011, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at Reinhart.  The Reinhart safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. 



These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan De

velopment.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.



DATA ELEMENTS NOTES



The RMP was recently updated with EPA according to the following reasons:

?    July 30, 2012 - submitted per the requirements of the five year revalidation. The re-submit was accidentally submitted as a correction rather than a revalidation.

?    August 14, 2012 - submitted as a revalidation. In addition, the program level was improperly registered (Program 2). The revalidation also included a submittal of Program 3.

?    August 27, 2012 - submitted to reflect current/new Hazard Assessment data and an updated Executive Summary based on an audit started on 8/20/2012.

?    July 25, 2013 - updated to incorporate new ownership and new RMP Responsible Person. Also, during an EPA inspection, the inspector noted that he felt that the "terrain" should be Rural instead of Urban so the worst case and alternative scenarios were updated.
